In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can create a function named `wrap_string` to wrap long strings into lines with a maximum width of 10 characters as follows:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(text, r"(?<=[\\s\\r\\n])+")
    lines = String[]
    current_line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + length(" ") > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = word
        else
            current_line *= word * " "
        end
    end

    push!(lines, current_line)
    join(lines, "\n")
end

# Example
text = "This is a very long string that needs to be wrapped at every 10 characters. It contains multiple words that should be wrapped correctly."
println(wrap_string(text))
```

This function takes a string as input and an optional `text_width` argument with a default value of 10. The function then splits the input string into words and iterates through them. If adding the current word would exceed the `text_width`, it creates a new line and continues with the next word. Once the input string has been processed, the function returns a string that consists of the wrapped lines.
